my computer. And my basic reason, motivation for this talk was to prove that even if you
don't think you have anything valuable on your computer, you probably do. In my mind,

on Quicken. Well, if I have a Windows 98 machine that is connected by default and I'm unfortunately

programs and they can get my password and they can pay my bills for me or their own.

you. Along the top axis are threat, OS, the type of technology, cable, DSL, or modem.
And then I'll just go down really briefly and explain this. Basically, the first threat
is the network neighborhood. Microsoft's infinite let's share our network with the world. Basically
Windows, technically Linux can be also classified in here. If you're using something called
Samba, Linux can export file systems just like Windows can. And the Samba, unfortunately
and Linux suffers from all of the same security problems in some respects that the Windows
one does unless you set it up right. And it's kind of hard to set up right. Basically, network
neighborhood exists as a threat on both cable, DSL, and modem. Now, the main differences
between cable, DSL, and modem, modem is generally intermittent unless you've got a leased line
or you know, some people have ISDN. Poor people. Anyways, they have ISDN and it's basically
up and down. Cable and DSL are what we call 24-7 connections. They're usually always on
and usually your computer's always connected. So the threat risk is much higher for cable
and DSL modem, and DSL as opposed to modem. DOS's denial of service, everything from the
ICMP fragmenting tax that people put out, the ones that took down Yahoo, and simple
